column5: The Welsh myth of the Gwiber describes it as a dragon-like, flying serpent with dangerous tendencies, a creature believed to emerge when snakes drank human milk, prevalent in southern Cardiganshire. A notable tale recalls a Gwiber that haunted Talybont's rocky cliffs and another in Trelech, Carmarthenshire, both eventually vanquished by local residents.

column3: A Flying Serpent At Newcastle Emlyn
column5: A gwiber, or Flying Serpent, appeared in Newcastle Emlyn, alighting on the castle and terrifying townsfolk during a fair day in the eighteenth century. A brave soldier successfully wounded the serpent by shooting at its unarmored navel from the river, leading to the creature's death and the staining of the river with its blood.
According to legend, this dragon resided in a cave beneath Wawel Hill, terrorizing the city until it was cunningly defeated by a young shoemaker.
This dragon was said to inhabit the area near the village of Mordiford, forming a unique bond with a young girl named Maud before becoming a threat to the community.
According to legend, this dragon resided in a cave beneath Wawel Hill, terrorizing the city until it was cunningly defeated by a young shoemaker.
The Knucker was a water dragon believed to dwell in a deep pool called the Knuckerhole near Lyminster, demanding livestock and causing havoc until it was outwitted and killed by a local hero.
A large dragon had its den on Bignor Hill, and marks of its folds were to be seen on the hill.

column3: The Dragon of St. Leonards Forest
column5: The dragon was killed after a long battle with St. Leonard
Described as the most frightening spirit in the area, a dragon-like creature who's sighting is a sure sign of approaching death.
From the folklore of the Alpine region of south-central Europe.

The Tarasque is a legendary dragon-like creature from medieval French folklore, said to have terrorized the region around Tarascon. Described as a hybrid of a lion, ox, scorpion, and turtle, it was ultimately tamed by Saint Martha, who led it peacefully to the townspeople.
According to the lore, the beast was excluded from Noah's Ark, yet survived the Deluge.
Unlucky enough to be captured by the Devil for use as a mount.
According to local folklore the hill at Knotlow was the lair of a dragon and the terraces around it were made by the coils of its tail.
A lake monster (or dragon) purported to live in Lagarfljót, a lake by the town of Egilsstaðir.
A dragon that lived in Gerundo Lake between Milan, Lodi and Cremona.
An ancient dragon python, who dwelled in the Loktak Lake of Manipur, in Meitei mythology and folklore. It is also referred to as "Loch Ness Monster of Manipur".
Cadborosaurus, nicknamed Caddy by journalist Archie Wills, is a sea serpent in the folklore of regions of the Pacific Coast of North America.
In American folklore, the snallygaster is a bird-reptile chimera originating in the superstitions of early German immigrants later combined with sensationalistic newspaper reports of the monster
Ljubljana’s protector and foe to Jason and the Argonauts.

The kuzuryū is a nine-headed Japanese dragon revered as a divine beast and local guardian deity in various parts of Japan. These dragons have power over rain and water, and are often associated with praying for rain, river health, and protection from floods.

The legend tells how Sir John Conyers slew the fearsome Sockburn Worm and was granted the surrounding lands, while his falchion became a celebrated relic. To this day, when a new Bishop of Durham first enters the diocese by crossing this bridge at Croft-on-Tees, the sword is ceremonially presented in memory of the dragon’s defeat.

column3: The Dragon at Castle Carlton Earthwork
column5: At Castle Carlton, a one-eyed, man-eating dragon prowled the storm-dark moat until Sir Hugh Bardolph faced it down; lightning blinded the beast and Hugh struck its one weak spot—a wart on its leg—to kill it. The overgrown motte and moat remain, and local lore says the place still remembers the dragon’s last stand

A great serpent was said to ravage South Ormsby until it was slain at nearby Walmsgate, and in another telling three dragons were hunted—one buried in the long barrow at Walmsgate, one dying at Ormsby, and one fleeing toward the Trent. The place-name “Wormsgate” was explained as the resting place of the slain beast
